name: Swift
title: This cheat sheet provides examples of using Swift that cover basic Swift knowledge, control flow etc.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: This cheat sheet provides examples of using Swift that cover basic Swift knowledge, control flow etc.

cards.title: Arithmetic operators
cards.body:
• `+` Add
• `-` Subtraction
• `*` Multiplication
• `/` Division
• `%` Remainder

```swift
var x = 0
x = 4 + 2 // x is now 6
x = 4 - 2 // x is now 2
x = 4 * 2 // x is now 8
x = 4 / 2 // x is now 2
x = 4 % 2 // x is now 0
```

• `+=` Adds and assigns sums
• `-=` subtract and assign the difference
• `*=` Multiplication and assignment
• `/=` Divide and assign quotient
• `%=` Divide and assign remainder

cards.title: Code Comments
cards.body:
```swift
// This line represents a comment in Swift.

/*
This is all commented out.
None will run!
*/
```

cards.title: Special comment syntax (MARK)
cards.body:
```swift
// MARK: -view settings
```

`MARK` can be used to display comments in the column

cards.title: Special comment syntax (TODO)
cards.body:
```swift
// TODO: update logic to accommodate data changes
```

`TODO` is used to display reminders of things that need to be done

cards.title: Special Comment Syntax (FIXME)
cards.body:
```swift
// FIXME: Fix buggy behavior when making changes to existing entries
```

`FIXME` is used to display reminders about things that need to be fixed

cards.title: Range Operators
cards.body: ```swift a...b // numbers between a and b (including both a and b) a.. -`a.. -`...b` One-Sided Range

cards.title: Logical Operators &&
cards.body:
```swift
true && true   // true
true && false  // false
false && true  // false
false && false // false
```

cards.title: Logical operators ||
cards.body:
```swift
true || true   // true
true || false  // true
false || true  // true
false || false // false
```

cards.title: Combined Logical Operators
cards.body:
```swift
!false && true || false // true
```

`!false && true` first evaluates and returns `true` Then, the expression, `true` || `false` evaluates and returns the
final result `true`

```swift
false || true && false // false
```

`true && false` first evaluates to return `false` Then, the expression, `false` || `false` evaluates and returns the
final result `false`

cards.title: Control the order of execution
stride() function
continue keyword
while loop
Initialize with array literal
Initialize with default value
.remove() and .removeAll() methods
cards.body:
```swift
var oddNumbers: Set = [1, 2, 3, 5]

// remove existing element
oddNumbers.remove(2)
// remove all elements
oddNumbers.removeAll()
```

cards.title: .isEmpty property
cards.body:
```swift
var emptyList = [String]()
print(emptyList.isEmpty)     // print: true

var populatedList: [Int] = [1, 2, 3]
print(populatedList.isEmpty) // print: false
```

cards.title: .isEmpty property
cards.body:
```swift
var emptySet = Set<String>()
print(emptySet.isEmpty)     // print: true

var populatedSet: Set = [1, 2, 3]
print(populatedSet.isEmpty) // print: false
```

cards.title: Initialize an empty dictionary
return value
cards.body:
```swift
let birthYear = 1994
var currentYear = 2020

func findAge() -> Int {
  return currentYear-birthYear
}

print(findAge()) // prints: 26
```

cards.title: Multiple parameters
Omit parameter labels
Parameters & Arguments
Optional parameters
cards.body:
```swift
func getFirstInitial(from name: String?) -> String? {
  return name?.first
}
```

Functions can accept optional types and return optional types. When a function cannot return a reasonable instance of
the requested type, it should return `nil`

cards.title: Structure Creation
Default property values
Inherit
This is an example of a struct definition and a class definition
Define the enumeration
cards.body:
```swift
enum Day {
  case monday
  case tuesday
  case wednesday
  case thursday
  case friday
  case saturday
  case sunday
}

let casualWorkday: Day = .friday
```

cards.title: CaseIterable
instance method
What are extensions?
cards.body:
Extensions is a way to add new add new functionality to existing classes, structures, enumerations, or protocol types.
This includes adding new methods, properties, initializers, and more.

cards.title: Extension syntax
Computed properties
Mutating methods
Initializers
What are generics?
cards.body:
Generics in Swift are a feature that allows us to create functions, classes, structures, and protocols that can work
with any data type.

cards.title: Why use generics?
cards.body:
Generics enable us to write clear and concise code that works with any data type. By using placeholders (like `T`), this
reduces the risk of introducing bugs.

cards.title: Type parameters
Generic Typealiases
cards.body:
Generic typealiases allow us to create a new name for an existing type (i.e., they would not introduce a new type).

```swift
typealias StringDictionary<T> = [String: T]
typealias IntFunction<T> = (Int) -> Int
typealias Vector<T> = (T, T, T)
```
